column1: Samut Prakan Province (Thai: จังหวัดสมุทรปราการ
column2: pronounced [sāmùt prāːkāːn] (listen)) Samut Prakan or Samutprakarn is one of the central provinces (changwat) of Thailand
column3: established by the Act Establishing Changwat Samut Prakan
column5: Changwat Samut Sakhon and Changwat Nakhon Nayok
column7: which came into force 9 May 1946.It is part of the Bangkok Metropolitan Region. Neighbouring provinces are Bangkok

column1: Suvarnabhumi Airport is in the Bang Phli District of Samut Prakan Province as well as the districts of Prawet
column2: Bang Kapi and Lat Krabang in neighbouring Bangkok city.

column1: == History ==
The province was created during the era of the Ayutthaya Kingdom
column2: with its administrative centre at Prapadaeng. It was the sea port of Siam
column5: and town walls. King Rama II started building the new centre at Samut Prakan in 1819
column6: after his predecessor King Taksin had abandoned the town fortifications. Altogether six forts were built on both sides of the Chao Phraya River
column7: and on an island in the river the pagoda
column9: was erected. These were involved in the Paknam incident of 13 July 1893
column10: which ended the Franco-Siamese War with a French naval blockade of Bangkok. Of the original six forts only two still exist today
column11: Phi Sua Samut and Phra Chulachomklao.

column1: == Toponymy ==
In Thai the word samut is from Sanskrit
column2: samudra
column4: and the word prakan is from Sanskrit

column1: == Geography ==
Samut Prakan lies at the mouth of the Chao Phraya River on the Gulf of Thailand. Thus the province is also sometimes called Pak Nam (ปากน้ำ)
column2: Thai for 'mouth of river'. The part of the province on the west side of the river consists mostly of rice paddies and shrimp farms as well as mangrove forests
column3: while the eastern part is the urban centre
column4: including industrial factories. It is part of the Bangkok metropolis. The urbanization on both sides of the provincial boundary is identical. The province has a coastline of approximately 47.2 kilometres.

column1: Samut Prakan is the site of a skirmish between French and Siamese forces on 13 July 1893
column2: subsequently referred to as the Paknam Incident. This battle resulted in a French victory and the signing of the Franco-Siamese Treaty of 3 October 1893 which ceded territory east of the Mekong River to France
column3: territory that forms much of modern Laos.

column1: == Symbols ==
The provincial seal shows the temple Phra Samut Chedi
column2: the most important site of Buddhist worship in the province.

column1: The provincial tree is Thespesia populnea.
== Administrative divisions ==
=== Provincial government ===
The province is divided into six districts (amphoes). The districts are further subdivided into 50 subdistricts (tambons) and 396 villages (mubans).
=== Local government ===

As of 13 May 2020 there are: one Samut Prakan Provincial Administrative Organization - PAO (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and twenty-two municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. The capital Samut Prakan has city (thesaban nakhon) status. Further seven have town (thesaban mueang) status and fourteen  subdistrict  municipalities (thesaban tambon).
The non-municipal areas are administered by twenty-seven Subdistrict Administrative Organizations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).
For national elections the province is divided into three voting districts
column2: one represented by three assemblymen and the other two each by two assemblymen.

column1: == Suvarnabhumi Airport ==

column2: ICAO: VTBS)
column3: also known as (New) Bangkok International Airport
column4: is one of two international airports serving Bangkok. The other one is Don Mueang International Airport. Suvarnabhumi covers an area of 3

column1: The airport is on what had formerly been known as Nong Nguhao (Cobra Swamp) in Racha Thewa in Bang Phli
column2: Samut Prakan Province
column3: about 25 kilometres (16 mi) east of downtown Bangkok. The terminal building was designed by Helmut Jahn of Murphy / Jahn Architects. It was constructed primarily by ITO JV. The airport has the world's tallest free-standing control tower (132.2 metres or 434 feet)
column4: and the world's fourth largest single-building airport terminal

column1: Suvarnabhumi is the twentieth busiest airport in the world
column2: sixth busiest airport in Asia
column3: and the busiest in the country
column5: and is also a major air cargo hub
column6: with a total of 95 airlines. On social networks
column7: Suvarnabhumi was the world's most popular site for taking Instagram photographs in 2012.The airport inherited the airport code
column9: from Don Mueang after the older airport ceased international commercial flights. Motorway 7 connects the airport

column12: where most export manufacturing takes place.

column1: == Bhumibol Bridge ==
The Bhumibol Bridge (Thai: สะพานภูมิพล)
column2: also known as the Industrial Ring Road Bridge (Thai: สะพานวงแหวนอุตสาหกรรม) is part of the 13 km long Industrial Ring Road connecting southern Bangkok with Samut Prakan Province. The bridge crosses the Chao Phraya River twice
column3: with two cable-stayed spans of lengths of 702 m and 582 m supported by two diamond-shaped pylons 173 m and 164 m high. Where the two spans meet
column4: another road rises to join them at a free-flowing interchange suspended 50 metres above the ground.

column1: The bridge opened for traffic on 20 September 2006
column2: before the official opening date of 5 December 2006. It is part of the Bangkok Industrial Ring Road
column3: a royal scheme initiated by King Bhumibol Adulyadej that aims to solve traffic problems within Bangkok and surrounding areas
column4: especially the industrial area around Khlong Toei Port

column1: According to tradition
column2: all the bridges over the Chao Phraya in Bangkok are named after a member of the royal family. In October 2009
column3: it was announced that both bridges would be named after King Bhumibol Adulyadej
column4: with the northern bridge officially named "Bhumibol 1 Bridge" and the southern bridge "Bhumibol 2 Bridge".The structure of the Bhumibol Bridge consists of two parts:

column1: Bhumibol Bridge 1 crosses the northern part of Chao Praya River connecting Yan Nawa District
column2: Bangkok and Song Khanong District
column3: Samut Prakan. It is a cable-stayed bridge with seven lanes together with two high pillars. The structure is reinforced concrete 50 m above the river to enable the passage of ships.

column1: Bhumibol Bridge 2 is the one across the southern part of Chao Praya River connecting Song Khanong District and Bang Ya Phraek District. The structure is similar to Bhumibol Bridge 1
column2: with seven lanes and two pillars built using reinforced concrete 50 m high.

column1: == Human Achievement Index 2017 ==
Since 2003
column2: the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Thailand has tracked progress on human development at sub-national level using the Human Achievement Index (HAI)
column3: a composite index covering eight key areas of human development. The National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB) has taken over this task since 2017.
